results.title: Taxi
results.creator_credit: Gerard Pires, Laurent Petin, Michael Petin and ARP-TF1 Films
results.brief_description: An upbeat and entertaining film from director Gerard Pires where the tale of charismatic and grandiose Daniel, a former pizza delivery boy turned taxi driver extraodinaire, is woven into the tragi-comic life of Emilien, an unsuccessful, down trodden policeman on a near hopeless search for illusive German bank robbers. The son of a rally car driver, with driving skills that seemingly defy the realms of possibility with his speed crazy efforts in a custom modified car brimming with gadgetry, Daniel unsuspectingly picks up Emilien from his mother’s house and inevitably sets out to give him a high-speed ride. Consequently, Daniel is forced to accept a deal as a driver and assistant detective for Emilien to avoid becoming a permanent pedestrian. So, from stages of ineptitude and absurdity the investigation into the German bank robbers continues but this time with Daniel uncomfortably placed on the other side of the law but nevertheless becoming a crucial mastermind along with Emilien in the pursuit of the bank robbers. With the help of a parade of pizza delivery boys, Daniel’s trusty taxi, the amiably long suffering women in both their lives and a little messing with envious egos the unlikely pair take the uncrackable case to its longed for conclusion. Cast includes Samy Naceri, Frederic Diefenthal, Marion Cotillard and Manuella Gourary. Spoken in French with English subtitles.

results.title: Taxation office
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The workings of the Taxation Department, as explained to a young man joining the department. This film serves as an introduction to new Taxation Department staff, and gives the man in the street an insight as to how the Department functions.

results.title: Tax: the outcome of income
results.creator_credit: Veronika Soul, Rupert Glover, Canada. Revenue Canada Customs, Excise and Taxation and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This montage of animated photographs and medieval drawings, superimposed on archival and contemporary film footage, traces the evolution of Canada’s system of taxation through the boom times and the bad times of Canadian history. The film examines the persistent struggle for tax revenue waged between federal and provincial governments since Confederation, and concludes with a fast-moving look at Canada’s modernized tax system.

results.title: Tax is not a four letter word
results.creator_credit: Michael Mills, Robert Verrall and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A musical cartoon produced for the Department of National Revenue, Canada. It is about the most misunderstood servant of us all, the income tax collector. But in this film he no longer remains unloved, unsung, once people understand that the money he collects is really for everyone’s benefit. A bright, amusing film for any time of year, tax time or not.

results.title: Tawny scrawny lion
results.creator_credit: Allan Frank Sandler, Zagreb Film and Sandler Institutional Films
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon about a scrawny lion who is always hungry and a rabbit who talks the lion out of eating all the other animals of the forest. The rabbit not only befriends the lion but finds a way to satisfy the lion’s hunger. Based on the book of the same title by Kathryn Jackson. Consultant Chuck Jones. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Taupo holiday
results.brief_description: Tourist promotion film of activities on and around Lake Taupo, New Zealand. Featured items include: Spa Hotel; Waikato River; Wairaki Valley and thermal activity; fishing for rainbow trout.

results.title: Tattoos
results.creator_credit: Mark Bayly and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Couchman over Australia”.
Peter Couchman hosts a studio discussion on tattoos and why people wear them. He leads a debate on whether tattoos should be recognised as a legitimate art form. The audience is shown a tattoo being applied during the debate.

results.title: Tattooed Tears
results.creator_credit: Joan Churchill, Nicholas Broomfield and Gogo Films
results.brief_description: Undaunted, indeed challenged, by the furore over `Juvenile Liason’ Nick Broomfield and Joan Churchill wanted to make another film about young offenders who had been institutionalised for the purposes of rehabilitation and training. Luckily, they found the Director of the California Youth Authority who, disillusioned and on the verge of retiring, was willing to give them carte blanche with the filming.

results.title: Tattoo 67
results.creator_credit: Yves Leduc, Michel Regnier, Clement Perron and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Highlights of the military spectacle that entertained Canadian audiences from coast to coast during Canada’s centennial celebrations, this major tribute of Canada’s armed forces took three years of preparation and involved over a thousand members. The three-hour program comprised parades and pageantry, historic tableaux, massed bands, drills and gymnastic displays. This film shows a little of each of the main events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yves Leduc, Michel Regnier, Clement Perron and ONF | NFB

results.title: Tati shorts
results.brief_description: The characters in these three short films will be familiar territory to fans of actor/director Jacques Tati. “Soigne ton Gauche=Watch your Left” (12 mins. 1936) directed by Rene Clement, focuses on a boxer whose training suffers considerable upheaval when he is joined in the ring by Tati bearing many traits of what would later become the Hulot character. This film has some French dialogue but the soundtrack is ambient rather than specific. “L’Ecole des Facteurs=School for Postmen” (15 mins. 1947) sees Tati approach his studies in a confused and enthusiastic manner. This character would go on to reap global fame as Francois the Postman in ‘Jour de Fete’. In “Cours du Soir=Evening Classes” (28 mins. 1967) Tati’s portrayal of a teacher presents an amalgam of Hulot and Francois allowing both characters full comic reign in the classroom.
